intro: Lappula patagonica, commonly known as the Patagonian lappula, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the family Chenopodiaceae and is characterized by its small, greenish-yellow flowers and succulent leaves. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, adapting to harsh conditions with its thick, fleshy stems and leaves. Its seeds are dispersed by wind, allowing it to colonize open, disturbed areas. Lappula patagonica is often found in grasslands and along riverbanks, where it plays a minor role in local ecosystems.
